answers.explanation: Starting high-dose β-blockers on the day of surgery increases stroke and hypotension risk; initiation, if indicated, should occur well in advance with careful titration, often guided by test results.

answers.text: Obtain resting transthoracic echocardiography to measure left ventricular ejection fraction
answers.explanation: Resting echocardiography is not indicated in clinically stable patients without heart failure symptoms or unexplained dyspnea and does not assess inducible ischemia relevant to perioperative risk.

answers.text: Proceed to surgery without further testing and use postoperative troponin surveillance only
answers.explanation: Skipping testing is reasonable only when risk is low/intermediate or results would not change management. Here, high surgical risk and multiple RCRI factors make stress testing useful to guide potential coronary evaluation or surgical timing.

answers.text: Order pharmacologic stress testing (eg, dobutamine stress echocardiography) prior to surgery
answers.explanation: Poor functional capacity with elevated perioperative risk (open vascular surgery, multiple RCRI factors) justifies noninvasive stress testing when results would change management; dobutamine stress echo is appropriate given limited exercise capacity and CKD.

answers.text: Refer directly for diagnostic coronary angiography before surgery
answers.explanation: Invasive angiography is not performed routinely before noncardiac surgery and is reserved for standard indications (eg, ACS or high-risk findings on noninvasive testing).

didactic:
ACC/AHA perioperative guidelines recommend a stepwise approach: (1) identify active cardiac conditions (eg, ACS, decompensated heart failure, severe arrhythmias, critical valvular disease), (2) estimate perioperative risk using surgical risk plus a clinical tool (eg, RCRI/NSQIP), and (3) assess functional capacity. Patients with ≥4 METs typically proceed without testing. In contrast, those with poor functional capacity (<4 METs) and elevated predicted risk (>1% major adverse cardiac events) may benefit from noninvasive testing only if the results would change management.

This patient faces high-risk surgery (open vascular) and has multiple RCRI factors (high-risk surgery, ischemic heart disease, insulin therapy, creatinine >2 mg/dL), conferring substantial cardiac risk. Because he lacks unstable symptoms but would consent to coronary evaluation/revascularization if high-risk ischemia is demonstrated, selective noninvasive stress testing is reasonable to guide management. For patients unable to exercise, pharmacologic tests are preferred:
- Dobutamine stress echocardiography (assesses inducible wall motion abnormalities; no contrast, favorable in CKD)
- Vasodilator nuclear perfusion imaging (assesses perfusion defects; also avoids iodinated contrast)

Routine testing that will not alter care should be avoided. Resting transthoracic echocardiography is reserved for unexplained dyspnea, suspected new/worsening heart failure, or significant valvular disease—not for stable coronary disease alone. Routine preoperative coronary angiography is not indicated absent standard triggers (eg, ACS or high-risk noninvasive findings). β-blockers should be continued if already prescribed; if initiating for ischemia risk, start weeks before surgery and titrate. If the patient would not undergo revascularization or surgery is urgent, stress testing should be deferred and perioperative management optimized instead.
educationalObjective: Use stress testing selectively in patients with poor functional capacity when results would change management.

questionText:
A 55-year-old man with major depressive disorder treated with venlafaxine XR 150 mg daily presents for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He is otherwise healthy and asks whether to take his antidepressant the morning of surgery. The default postoperative order set includes tramadol for moderate pain and meperidine for shivering. Standard PONV prophylaxis at your institution is dexamethasone and ondansetron. Which perioperative medication plan is most appropriate to minimize risk while maintaining psychiatric stability?

Which of the following is the best plan?

answers.text: Continue venlafaxine on the day of surgery; avoid tramadol and meperidine; use hydromorphone for analgesia and dexmedetomidine for shivering if needed.
answers.explanation: Most SSRIs/SNRIs should be continued perioperatively. Avoid strongly serotonergic agents (eg, tramadol, meperidine) and select nonserotonergic alternatives (eg, morphine/hydromorphone for pain, dexmedetomidine for shivering).

answers.text: Switch venlafaxine to phenelzine 1 week preoperatively and use meperidine for shivering because the MAOI will prevent serotonin excess.
answers.explanation: MAOIs markedly increase the risk of hypertensive crisis and serotonin syndrome with multiple perioperative drugs; meperidine is contraindicated with MAOIs.

answers.text: Hold venlafaxine for 2 weeks preoperatively; use tramadol for analgesia and ondansetron for PONV prophylaxis.
answers.explanation: Abrupt discontinuation of SNRIs can cause withdrawal and relapse. Tramadol is serotonergic and increases risk of serotonin syndrome when combined with SNRIs.

answers.text: Continue venlafaxine and use methylene blue intraoperatively if vasoplegia occurs.
answers.explanation: Methylene blue is a potent MAO inhibitor and can precipitate life-threatening serotonin syndrome in patients taking SSRIs/SNRIs.

answers.text: Hold venlafaxine on the morning of surgery to reduce bleeding risk; use ketorolac for opioid-sparing analgesia and meperidine for shivering.
answers.explanation: Withholding a single dose does not meaningfully change bleeding risk and risks withdrawal. Ketorolac plus an SSRI/SNRI increases bleeding risk, and meperidine is serotonergic.

didactic:
Most patients should continue SSRIs/SNRIs perioperatively to avoid discontinuation syndrome (anxiety, agitation, dizziness) and relapse of depression. Abrupt cessation does not meaningfully reduce bleeding or interaction risks in the short term and may worsen postoperative outcomes. The major anesthetic considerations are platelet dysfunction and drug–drug interactions that can precipitate serotonin syndrome.

SSRIs/SNRIs inhibit platelet 5‑HT uptake, modestly increasing bleeding risk, which is amplified by NSAIDs and other antiplatelet agents. This effect does not warrant routine discontinuation; instead, minimize additional platelet inhibitors when feasible.

Serotonin syndrome presents with mental status changes, autonomic instability (hyperthermia, tachycardia), and neuromuscular hyperactivity (clonus, hyperreflexia). It is most often triggered when chronic serotonergic antidepressants are combined with potent serotonergic or MAO‑inhibiting drugs. High‑risk perioperative agents include:

- MAO inhibitors: methylene blue (potent), linezolid
- Serotonergic opioids: tramadol, meperidine > methadone; fentanyl has rare case reports
- Others: dextromethorphan, St. John’s wort

Preferred strategies:

- Continue SSRI/SNRI on the day of surgery.
- Use nonserotonergic analgesics (eg, morphine, hydromorphone) and multimodal adjuncts (acetaminophen, regional techniques). Avoid tramadol and meperidine.
- Treat postoperative shivering with nonserotonergic options (eg, dexmedetomidine or clonidine) rather than meperidine.
- Standard antiemetics (eg, dexamethasone, 5‑HT3 antagonists like ondansetron) are generally safe; case reports of serotonin syndrome with 5‑HT3 antagonists are rare and mechanistically unlikely.
- If an MAO‑inhibiting agent (eg, methylene blue, linezolid) is essential, consult psychiatry; avoid the MAOI if possible, or plan a supervised antidepressant washout with appropriate timing.

Thus, the safest plan is to continue venlafaxine and avoid strongly serotonergic perioperative drugs, selecting hydromorphone for analgesia and dexmedetomidine for shivering.
educationalObjective: Continue SSRIs/SNRIs and most antidepressants while preparing for potential drug interactions (e.g., serotonin syndrome).

questionText:
A 45-year-old man with focal epilepsy controlled on carbamazepine ER 400 mg BID and lamotrigine 150 mg BID presents for emergent laparotomy for small-bowel obstruction. He has been vomiting, an NG tube is placed to low continuous suction, and the surgeon anticipates a postoperative ileus for 2–3 days. He took his last antiepileptic doses yesterday evening and cannot tolerate oral medications. Renal and hepatic function are normal.

Which perioperative management is most appropriate to prevent withdrawal seizures?

answers.text: Place an NG tube and administer crushed carbamazepine ER and lamotrigine via the tube in PACU.
answers.explanation: Enteral absorption is unreliable with ileus and NG suction, and carbamazepine ER should not be crushed; this does not ensure therapeutic levels.

answers.text: Initiate scheduled IV levetiracetam 1 g q12h now and continue until enteral intake returns.
answers.explanation: Chronic antiepileptics should be continued perioperatively; in patients who are NPO without IV forms of home agents (eg, carbamazepine, lamotrigine), substitute a parenteral agent such as IV levetiracetam on a scheduled basis until oral therapy resumes.

answers.text: Increase sevoflurane to ≥1.5 MAC intraoperatively to suppress seizures; no additional prophylaxis needed.
answers.explanation: Volatile anesthetics do not prevent postoperative withdrawal seizures once discontinued and are not a substitute for ongoing antiepileptic therapy.

answers.text: Administer a single IV lorazepam 2 mg dose preinduction for seizure prophylaxis.
answers.explanation: A single benzodiazepine dose is short-acting and insufficient to replace scheduled antiepileptic therapy over days of NPO status.

answers.text: Hold antiepileptic drugs until oral intake resumes; treat seizures PRN with midazolam.
answers.explanation: Withholding chronic antiepileptics markedly increases withdrawal seizure risk; PRN benzodiazepines do not provide continuous seizure prophylaxis.

didactic:
Patients on chronic antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) should have therapy **continued perioperatively** to avoid withdrawal seizures. Missing even 1–2 scheduled doses can precipitate seizures, particularly when physiologic stress, sleep deprivation, and fluctuating anesthetic depth coexist. If the patient cannot take oral medications, a **parenteral substitution** should be instituted on a scheduled basis.

Key principles:
- Continue home AEDs with sips of water preoperatively when safe; otherwise plan **IV substitution** in advance.
- Many AEDs lack IV formulations (eg, **carbamazepine, lamotrigine, oxcarbazepine, topiramate**), necessitating substitution.
- AEDs with available IV forms include **levetiracetam, valproate, fosphenytoin/phenytoin, phenobarbital, lacosamide**.
- **Levetiracetam** is often preferred for substitution due to minimal drug–drug interactions, 1:1 IV:PO conversion, and convenient dosing (eg, 500–1500 mg IV q12h; adjust for renal impairment).
- Enteral delivery via NG/OG is acceptable only when GI absorption is reliable; **ileus or NG suction** makes absorption unpredictable, and some formulations (eg, **carbamazepine ER**) should not be crushed.

Benzodiazepines are appropriate for treatment of **acute seizures**, but intermittent dosing does not provide continuous prophylaxis during prolonged NPO periods. Increasing volatile anesthetic depth intraoperatively does not protect against **postoperative** withdrawal once anesthetic delivery ceases. Coordination with neurology and early orders for scheduled IV AEDs help maintain therapeutic drug exposure and prevent breakthrough seizures. Resume the patient’s home regimen as soon as enteral intake is feasible, transitioning off the temporary IV agent. Consider comorbidities when selecting a substitute (eg, avoid valproate in thrombocytopenia or significant hepatic disease; phenytoin/fosphenytoin induces CYP enzymes and may increase nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocker requirements).
educationalObjective: Continue antiepileptic drugs and plan IV substitution if NPO to prevent withdrawal seizures.

questionText:
A 65-year-old man with hypertension and stable coronary artery disease (remote MI 5 years ago, EF 55%) is scheduled for elective total knee arthroplasty under general anesthesia. He takes metoprolol succinate 50 mg daily, amlodipine 10 mg daily, atorvastatin 40 mg nightly, hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily, and furosemide 20 mg as needed (last taken 2 weeks ago). He reports no angina, dyspnea, or orthopnea. Vitals today: BP 128/72, HR 62, SpO<sub>2</sub> 98% on room air. Exam shows clear lungs, normal JVP, no edema. Labs: Na 138 mEq/L, K 3.6 mEq/L, creatinine 0.9 mg/dL. He is NPO since midnight and appears euvolemic.

Which of the following medication plans is most appropriate for the morning of surgery?

answers.text: Continue metoprolol, amlodipine, and atorvastatin; hold hydrochlorothiazide and furosemide
answers.explanation: Best choice: continue chronic β-blocker, statin, and calcium channel blocker; individualize diuretics—hold in a euvolemic patient to reduce perioperative hypotension, electrolyte derangements, and AKI risk.

answers.text: Continue metoprolol and atorvastatin; hold amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, and furosemide
answers.explanation: Unnecessarily withholding a calcium channel blocker can worsen perioperative blood pressure control; most CCBs should be continued.

answers.text: Hold all antihypertensives; continue only atorvastatin
answers.explanation: Global withholding of antihypertensives risks rebound hypertension and β-blocker withdrawal; targeted continuation of β-blockers and CCBs is preferred, with diuretics individualized.

answers.text: Continue amlodipine and diuretics; hold metoprolol and atorvastatin
answers.explanation: Abrupt β-blocker withdrawal increases perioperative tachycardia and ischemia; statins should be continued given cardioprotective benefits.

answers.text: Hold metoprolol due to bradycardia; continue amlodipine, atorvastatin, and diuretics
answers.explanation: A resting HR of 62 bpm is not a contraindication to continuing a chronic β-blocker; continuing diuretics in a euvolemic NPO patient increases hypotension and electrolyte risk.

didactic:
Perioperative management of chronic cardiovascular medications should balance prevention of adverse hemodynamics with avoidance of withdrawal phenomena and cardiac events.

- β-blockers: Chronic β-blockers should be continued perioperatively. Abrupt cessation can provoke rebound tachycardia, hypertension, and myocardial ischemia due to β-receptor upregulation. Continuation reduces perioperative myocardial ischemia and arrhythmias. Dose adjustments may be considered for significant bradycardia or AV block, but HR 60–70 bpm is acceptable.
- Statins: Continue statins. They reduce perioperative major adverse cardiac events via plaque stabilization, anti-inflammatory effects, and improved endothelial function. Initiation is reasonable in high-risk vascular surgery, but withholding chronic therapy is not indicated.
- Calcium channel blockers: Most CCBs (dihydropyridine and non-dihydropyridine) are continued. They provide stable BP control and coronary vasodilation. Caution is warranted only with significant bradycardia/AV block when using verapamil/diltiazem or in severe LV dysfunction, but routine withholding is not recommended.
- Diuretics: Individualize based on volume status and indication. In euvolemic NPO patients, holding morning thiazide and loop diuretics reduces risks of intravascular depletion, hypotension, hypokalemia, and perioperative AKI. Continue diuretics if there is clear volume overload (eg, decompensated heart failure with edema, elevated JVP), pulmonary congestion, or difficult BP control that depends on diuresis.

In this stable, euvolemic patient, the optimal plan is to continue metoprolol, amlodipine, and atorvastatin while holding hydrochlorothiazide and furosemide on the morning of surgery. This strategy preserves cardioprotection and hemodynamic stability while minimizing renal and electrolyte complications from unnecessary diuresis.
educationalObjective: Continue beta‑blockers, statins, and most calcium channel blockers; individualize diuretics based on volume status.

questionText: A 68-year-old man with moderate COPD (FEV1 55% predicted) is scheduled for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. He takes tiotropium daily and a salmeterol/fluticasone inhaler twice daily, with albuterol as needed (about twice weekly). He skipped his morning inhalers because he is NPO. Vitals are normal; SpO<sub>2</sub> is 94% on room air. Examination reveals mild expiratory wheezes without distress and no signs of acute infection. Which preoperative management is most appropriate to reduce the risk of perioperative bronchospasm?

answers.text: Withhold the inhaled corticosteroid to reduce the risk of oropharyngeal candidiasis and proceed without bronchodilator therapy.
answers.explanation: Inhaled corticosteroids should be continued perioperatively; withholding them increases airway inflammation. Preoperative bronchodilator therapy decreases perioperative bronchospasm risk.

answers.text: Administer 100 mg IV hydrocortisone as stress-dose steroids because he uses inhaled fluticasone and avoid β<sub>2</sub>-agonists due to tachycardia risk.
answers.explanation: Stress-dose steroids are indicated for chronic systemic steroid use, not for isolated inhaled corticosteroids. β<sub>2</sub>-agonists are first-line for preoperative bronchodilation and are safe in stable patients.

answers.text: Continue his inhaled tiotropium and salmeterol/fluticasone on the day of surgery and administer a nebulized albuterol/ipratropium treatment before induction.
answers.explanation: Continuing long-acting inhaled bronchodilators and steroids and giving short-acting bronchodilator therapy preoperatively optimizes airway caliber and reduces bronchospasm risk without delaying surgery.

answers.text: Delay surgery and start a 5-day course of oral prednisone to optimize lung function, then reassess.
answers.explanation: Short systemic steroid courses are reserved for poorly controlled disease or acute exacerbation. This patient is near baseline; optimization can be achieved with inhaled therapy without delaying surgery.

answers.text: Obtain preoperative spirometry and a chest radiograph to guide risk stratification before proceeding.
answers.explanation: Routine PFTs and chest imaging do not improve outcomes in stable, known COPD and may delay care. Immediate optimization with inhaled bronchodilators is more impactful.

didactic:
Patients with COPD/asthma are at heightened risk for perioperative bronchospasm due to airway hyperreactivity, particularly with airway manipulation. To minimize this risk, continue all **inhaled maintenance therapies** on the day of surgery, including long-acting β<sub>2</sub>-agonists (LABA), long-acting muscarinic antagonists (LAMA), and inhaled corticosteroids (ICS). Being NPO does not preclude the use of inhalers or nebulized treatments.

Preoperative optimization typically includes a dose of **short-acting bronchodilator** therapy (eg, albuterol) shortly before induction; combining with an anticholinergic (ipratropium) provides additive bronchodilation in COPD. This strategy improves airway caliber, reduces dynamic hyperinflation during positive-pressure ventilation, and lowers the incidence of intraoperative bronchospasm.

Systemic corticosteroids should be reserved for patients with an **acute exacerbation** or poorly controlled symptoms (eg, increased dyspnea, wheeze, or rescue inhaler use) despite optimal inhaled therapy. In such cases, a short course of oral prednisone or IV methylprednisolone can be considered. Importantly, isolated ICS use **does not warrant stress-dose steroids**; adrenal suppression is primarily a concern with chronic systemic glucocorticoids.

Routine preoperative spirometry or chest imaging is **not indicated** in stable patients with known COPD/asthma because results rarely change immediate perioperative management and can delay care. Instead, focus on therapies that directly improve airflow before induction.

Additional intraoperative considerations include minimizing airway irritation (eg, use sevoflurane for its bronchodilatory properties), ensuring adequate depth of anesthesia before instrumentation, and promptly treating bronchospasm with inhaled β<sub>2</sub>-agonists ± anticholinergics; refractory cases may respond to epinephrine, ketamine, or magnesium. In summary, continue inhaled bronchodilators and steroids on the day of surgery and provide preoperative bronchodilator therapy when needed to reduce perioperative pulmonary complications.
educationalObjective: Continue inhaled bronchodilators and steroids in COPD/asthma and give preop bronchodilator optimization when needed.

questionText:
A 62-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus, obesity, OSA, and CKD stage 3b (eGFR 35 mL/min/1.73 m²) is scheduled for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy today. His diabetes regimen includes insulin glargine 40 units at 22:00, insulin lispro with meals, metformin 1000 mg twice daily, empagliflozin 25 mg daily, and weekly semaglutide. His case was moved from 07:30 to 15:00. He took empagliflozin yesterday morning, semaglutide 5 days ago, and his usual glargine at 22:00. He is NPO since midnight, denies GI symptoms, and has a preop glucose of 85 mg/dL with negative urine ketones. Vitals are stable.

Which perioperative diabetes plan is most appropriate for this elective case?

answers.text: Proceed today; hold empagliflozin only the morning of surgery, hold metformin, give 100% basal insulin, use subcutaneous correction scale, and target 110–140 mg/dL.
answers.explanation: Holding an SGLT2 inhibitor only on the day of surgery is insufficient (requires ≥3 days); full basal dose with afternoon surgery and low glucose increases hypoglycemia risk, and subcutaneous correction alone is suboptimal for prolonged cases.

answers.text: Proceed today; stop all insulin to avoid hypoglycemia, start a D5 infusion only, and target 70–110 mg/dL intraoperatively.
answers.explanation: Withholding basal insulin risks ketosis/DKA, especially with SGLT2 exposure; dextrose alone worsens hyperglycemia and a 70–110 mg/dL target is too strict.

answers.text: Postpone surgery until ≥3 days after the last empagliflozin dose; on the rescheduled date hold metformin, give 70–80% of usual glargine the night before, manage intraoperatively with dextrose and insulin infusion to maintain 140–180 mg/dL.
answers.explanation: SGLT2 inhibitors should be held for at least 3 days preop to reduce euglycemic DKA risk; with CKD, hold metformin on the day of surgery; reduce but continue basal insulin to prevent ketosis, and use insulin/dextrose to maintain a 140–180 mg/dL target during anesthesia.

answers.text: Proceed today; continue full basal insulin without dextrose, hold only prandial insulin, and target 80–110 mg/dL intraoperatively.
answers.explanation: Continuing full basal without dextrose risks hypoglycemia (glucose 85 mg/dL, prolonged fast), and a tight 80–110 mg/dL target increases hypoglycemia; this plan ignores SGLT2-associated euglycemic DKA risk.

answers.text: Delay surgery 24 hours; continue all oral agents, give half-dose basal insulin, and target <140 mg/dL intraoperatively.
answers.explanation: A 24-hour delay is inadequate for SGLT2 washout; continuing orals while NPO is unsafe, and a <140 mg/dL target is unnecessarily tight.

didactic:
Perioperative diabetes management balances hypoglycemia avoidance with prevention of ketosis and hyperglycemia-related complications. For most noncritically ill adults, intraoperative glucose targets of 140–180 mg/dL are recommended; tighter targets increase hypoglycemia without clear outcome benefit.

SGLT2 inhibitors (eg, empagliflozin) increase ketogenesis and can cause euglycemic DKA during fasting, illness, or insulin deficiency. For elective surgery, hold SGLT2 inhibitors for at least 3 days (ertugliflozin 4 days). If the medication was taken within this window, postponing elective procedures is prudent; proceeding risks euglycemic DKA despite normal or mildly elevated glucose. Monitor for ketosis if recent exposure is suspected.

Long-acting basal insulin should typically be continued but reduced to mitigate hypoglycemia during fasting. A practical approach is 70–80% of the usual dose the night before (or morning-of if that is the patient’s schedule). Do not stop basal insulin entirely, as this promotes lipolysis and ketone production. Prandial insulin is held while NPO; use IV insulin infusion for major or prolonged cases, particularly when timing is variable, to achieve a 140–180 mg/dL target with frequent monitoring. Provide dextrose (eg, D5 or D10) when needed to prevent hypoglycemia and to allow safe insulin administration.

Metformin is generally held on the morning of surgery and avoided perioperatively in patients with renal impairment, tissue hypoperfusion, or anticipated contrast exposure due to lactic acidosis risk. Sulfonylureas are held the day of surgery to avoid hypoglycemia. GLP-1 receptor agonists can delay gastric emptying; many centers individualize continuation versus holding based on GI symptoms and aspiration risk.

In this case, recent empagliflozin necessitates delaying an elective operation until adequate washout, holding metformin on the operative day (CKD), continuing reduced basal insulin, and using dextrose/insulin intraoperatively to maintain 140–180 mg/dL.
educationalObjective: Create a perioperative diabetes plan: basal insulin adjustments, perioperative glucose targets, and hold of hypoglycemics that increase risk.

questionText: A 68-year-old man with hypertension and CKD stage 3 (Cr 1.7 mg/dL) is scheduled for elective laparoscopic sigmoid resection under general anesthesia with pneumoperitoneum and PEEP. Home medications include amlodipine 10 mg daily, valsartan 160 mg daily, and hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily. He took no medications this morning and is euvolemic on exam; BP in preop is 128/72 mmHg, HR 72/min. You anticipate hemodynamic lability with insufflation and induction. Which preoperative antihypertensive plan and vasopressor readiness is most appropriate for this patient?

answers.text: Hold valsartan and give a large crystalloid bolus before induction; no vasopressors need to be prepared if the patient is euvolemic
answers.explanation: Volume loading alone does not prevent vasoplegia and may be harmful in CKD; vasopressor readiness, particularly vasopressin, is still indicated.

answers.text: Hold both valsartan and amlodipine; plan to treat hypotension with ephedrine and avoid vasopressin
answers.explanation: Calcium channel blockers are typically continued; ephedrine may be less effective in vasoplegia, and avoiding vasopressin removes a key therapy for ACEI/ARB-associated hypotension.

answers.text: Continue valsartan on the morning of surgery and prepare phenylephrine as the primary rescue vasopressor
answers.explanation: Continuing an ARB increases the risk of refractory intraoperative hypotension, and catecholamines like phenylephrine may be less effective when the renin–angiotensin system is blocked.

answers.text: Hold only hydrochlorothiazide and continue valsartan; treat expected hypotension with a norepinephrine infusion alone
answers.explanation: Holding the diuretic can mitigate hypovolemia, but continuing the ARB still predisposes to vasoplegia; norepinephrine may help but vasopressin often provides superior response in RAS-blocked patients.

answers.text: Hold valsartan on the morning of surgery, continue amlodipine, and have vasopressin immediately available for hypotension refractory to catecholamines
answers.explanation: Withholding ACEIs/ARBs reduces the risk of vasoplegic hypotension; if hypotension occurs, vasopressin targets V1 receptors and is effective when catecholamines are less responsive.

didactic:
ACE inhibitors (ACEIs) and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) impair physiologic vasoconstriction mediated by the renin–angiotensin–aldosterone system. During anesthesia—especially with induction, pneumoperitoneum, and PEEP—sympathetic tone falls and afterload can drop precipitously. When the RAS is blocked, patients are at increased risk of **vasoplegic hypotension** that may be resistant to catecholamines. Multiple observational studies and meta-analyses show higher rates of intraoperative hypotension and vasopressor use when ACEIs/ARBs are continued on the day of surgery, without clear mortality benefit. Accordingly, many perioperative pathways recommend withholding the morning dose (≈24 hours preop) in patients at risk for hypotension undergoing noncardiac surgery.

In contrast, most other antihypertensives are continued. **Calcium channel blockers** (eg, amlodipine) are generally maintained perioperatively. **Diuretics** are often held the morning of surgery to reduce hypovolemia and electrolyte derangements, particularly in CKD.

When hypotension occurs in RAS-blocked or vasoplegic states, **vasopressin** is effective because it activates V1 receptors causing potent vasoconstriction independent of α-adrenergic pathways. Catecholamines (phenylephrine, ephedrine, norepinephrine) may still be used, but response can be blunted when the RAS is inhibited; adding vasopressin often restores vascular tone. Practical readiness includes having vasopressin available for bolus (eg, 0.5–1 unit) and/or infusion (eg, 0.03 units/min) if hypotension is refractory to fluids and catecholamines.

For this CKD patient on an ARB undergoing laparoscopic surgery with anticipated hemodynamic swings, the best approach is to:
- **Hold the ARB the morning of surgery** (reduce vasoplegia risk)
- **Continue the calcium channel blocker** (safe and maintains BP control)
- **Prepare vasopressin** for catecholamine-refractory hypotension, while using balanced fluids judiciously

This strategy minimizes preventable hypotension and ensures an effective rescue plan if vasoplegia develops.
educationalObjective: Decide on holding ACE inhibitors/ARBs preop in patients at risk of hypotension and plan vasopressor readiness.

questionText:
A 68-year-old man with Parkinson disease (PD) takes carbidopa-levodopa 25/100 mg every 3 hours and rasagiline 1 mg daily. He reports marked worsening of tremor and rigidity if doses are delayed. He is scheduled for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy at 11:00 and has been NPO since midnight. He has a history of severe postoperative nausea and vomiting after general anesthesia. Vitals and exam are otherwise unremarkable.

Which perioperative plan is most appropriate to minimize PD symptom exacerbation while providing effective PONV prophylaxis?

answers.text: Convert PD therapy to IV haloperidol while NPO; give promethazine at induction to prevent PONV.
answers.explanation: Haloperidol and promethazine have dopamine antagonism and can markedly worsen PD symptoms; there is no role for haloperidol to substitute PD therapy.

answers.text: Apply a scopolamine patch preoperatively and give metoclopramide at emergence; resume levodopa only after oral intake returns.
answers.explanation: Delaying levodopa risks parkinsonism–hyperpyrexia–like deterioration, and metoclopramide’s D2 blockade can worsen PD despite scopolamine use.

answers.text: Hold PD medications the morning of surgery; administer metoclopramide 10 mg IV at induction and postoperatively as needed.
answers.explanation: Withholding levodopa risks acute PD worsening; metoclopramide is a central D2 antagonist that can precipitate rigidity, akinesia, and dystonia in PD patients.

answers.text: Administer the usual morning carbidopa-levodopa dose with a small sip of water up to 1 hour preoperatively; give ondansetron and dexamethasone for PONV prophylaxis.
answers.explanation: Continuing levodopa minimizes perioperative PD exacerbation, and ondansetron plus dexamethasone provide effective prophylaxis without dopamine antagonism.

answers.text: Continue rasagiline but hold levodopa to reduce aspiration risk; avoid ondansetron and use prochlorperazine for PONV prophylaxis.
answers.explanation: Holding levodopa is inappropriate; prochlorperazine is a D2 antagonist that worsens PD, and ondansetron is safe in PD.

didactic:
Patients with Parkinson disease should have dopaminergic therapy **continued on schedule** perioperatively to prevent rigidity, akinesia, and parkinsonism–hyperpyrexia–like syndromes. Levodopa has a short half-life (1–3 hours); even brief interruptions can cause symptom rebound. Practical strategies include: scheduling early case times, administering the morning dose with a small sip of water despite NPO status, and planning enteral dosing (eg, via NG/duodenal tube) if prolonged NPO is expected. For longer NPO courses, transdermal rotigotine can be considered in consultation with neurology.

Avoid **dopamine antagonists** that worsen PD, including:
- Metoclopramide (D2 antagonist)
- Droperidol and haloperidol (butyrophenones)
- Prochlorperazine and promethazine (phenothiazines with D2 activity)
These agents can precipitate severe rigidity, tremor, and dystonia, complicating ventilation and recovery.

Use **non–dopaminergic antiemetics** for PONV prophylaxis:
- Ondansetron (5-HT3 antagonist)
- Dexamethasone
- Scopolamine
- Aprepitant
These provide effective prophylaxis without antagonizing dopamine receptors.

Selective MAO-B inhibitors (eg, rasagiline, selegiline) are typically **continued** perioperatively. Be cautious with serotonergic or monoaminergic analgesics (eg, meperidine, tramadol, methadone) due to rare but serious interaction risk; standard opioids (eg, fentanyl, hydromorphone) and 5-HT3 antagonists are generally acceptable. When oral intake is delayed, early reinitiation of dopaminergic therapy via non-oral routes prevents decompensation.

Bottom line: Continue levodopa on schedule and avoid D2-blocking antiemetics; choose ondansetron ± dexamethasone (and other non-dopaminergic options) for PONV prophylaxis in PD patients.
educationalObjective: Maintain Parkinson disease medications and avoid dopamine antagonists that worsen symptoms.

questionText:
A 58-year-old woman with BMI 40 kg/m<sup>2</sup>, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and obstructive sleep apnea presents for an elective laparoscopic hysterectomy under general anesthesia. She started weekly semaglutide 5 weeks ago and her dose was increased 7 days ago. Since the dose increase, she reports persistent nausea and early satiety. Her last semaglutide dose was 3 days ago. She has followed standard fasting guidelines (no solids for 10 hours, clear liquids until 3 hours preop). Vitals and exam are unremarkable; point-of-care glucose is 142 mg/dL.

Which perioperative plan is the best next step to mitigate aspiration risk while appropriately managing her GLP‑1 therapy?

answers.text: Defer elective surgery until gastrointestinal symptoms resolve and the dose‑escalation phase is complete; continue semaglutide and coordinate interim glycemic management.
answers.explanation: Symptomatic patients in the GLP‑1 dose‑escalation phase are at highest risk for delayed gastric emptying; deferring elective surgery is preferred. Continuing therapy avoids destabilizing diabetes while outpatient optimization occurs.

answers.text: Perform bedside gastric ultrasound now; if the antrum appears empty in supine and right lateral decubitus, proceed with standard induction today.
answers.explanation: Gastric ultrasound is useful when surgery cannot be delayed, but in a symptomatic, elective case during dose escalation, deferral is safer; ultrasound is operator dependent and may miss retained solids.

answers.text: Proceed today with rapid-sequence induction and endotracheal intubation, and hold semaglutide for 1 week postoperatively.
answers.explanation: RSI reduces but does not eliminate risk from retained solids; withholding the drug postoperatively does not address the current high-risk state and may worsen glycemic control.

answers.text: Administer metoclopramide and erythromycin preoperatively and proceed after 2 hours of clear liquids.
answers.explanation: Prokinetics and additional clear liquids do not reliably clear retained solids in GLP‑1–related delayed gastric emptying and are insufficient for aspiration risk mitigation.

answers.text: Proceed with general anesthesia today using standard fasting guidelines and continue semaglutide perioperatively.
answers.explanation: Standard fasting does not mitigate the elevated aspiration risk from delayed gastric emptying in symptomatic patients during GLP‑1 dose escalation.

didactic:
GLP‑1 receptor agonists (eg, semaglutide, tirzepatide, liraglutide) slow gastric emptying via vagal and central mechanisms, increasing the risk of residual solids despite standard fasting. Cases of retained gastric contents and aspiration during anesthesia have been reported, particularly in patients with high‑risk features. According to 2024 multi‑society guidance, most patients can continue GLP‑1 therapy perioperatively; risk mitigation focuses on identifying patients at increased risk and tailoring the plan accordingly.

High‑risk features include:
- Active gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, vomiting, early satiety, abdominal pain)
- Early dose‑escalation phase or high doses
- Known or suspected gastroparesis, prior gastric surgery, or other causes of delayed emptying

For elective procedures in high‑risk patients, the preferred approach is to defer surgery until symptoms resolve and the dose‑escalation phase is complete. When surgery must proceed, risk‑reduction strategies include a 24‑hour liquid‑only diet, point‑of‑care gastric ultrasound to assess for retained contents, and “full‑stomach” precautions (eg, RSI with cuffed endotracheal tube, avoidance of supraglottic devices). In urgent or emergent cases, manage as a full stomach regardless of fasting duration.

Withholding GLP‑1 agents may worsen glycemic control and appetite regulation; routine discontinuation is not recommended for most patients. If therapy is held for specific reasons, coordinate alternative diabetes management (eg, basal insulin adjustments) to maintain euglycemia and avoid ketosis. Prokinetics (metoclopramide, erythromycin) and additional clear liquids do not reliably resolve retained solids from GLP‑1–induced gastric stasis. Gastric ultrasound is valuable when available and performed by trained clinicians, but a negative study does not supersede concerning symptoms in an elective case. The safest course for this symptomatic patient during dose escalation is to postpone the procedure and optimize outpatient management.
educationalObjective: Manage GLP‑1 receptor agonists with attention to delayed gastric emptying and aspiration risk mitigation.

questionText:
A 67-year-old man with treatment-resistant major depression managed with phenelzine 60 mg/day for 8 months presents for urgent open reduction and internal fixation of an intertrochanteric femur fracture in 6 hours. He took his morning dose today. Other medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. He is hemodynamically stable, and the surgeon prefers not to delay surgery. You anticipate neuraxial or general anesthesia with possible intraoperative hypotension and postoperative shivering.

Which perioperative plan best minimizes serious drug interaction risk related to this medication while maintaining hemodynamic safety?

answers.text: Continue phenelzine; prefer ephedrine over direct-acting vasopressors because MAO inhibition reduces responsiveness to direct agonists; meperidine is acceptable if carefully titrated.
answers.explanation: Direct-acting vasopressors are preferred and effective; indirect agents like ephedrine are risky. Meperidine is contraindicated with MAOIs due to serotonin toxicity.

answers.text: Proceed without delaying surgery; continue phenelzine; treat hypotension with small, titrated doses of direct-acting vasopressors (eg, phenylephrine, epinephrine); avoid meperidine and indirect sympathomimetics (eg, ephedrine); involve psychiatry only if considering longer-term changes to antidepressant therapy.
answers.explanation: Irreversible MAOIs should generally be continued for urgent surgery; use direct-acting vasopressors and avoid meperidine and indirect sympathomimetics to prevent serotonin syndrome and hypertensive crisis. Psychiatry consultation is appropriate only if planning a washout, which requires at least 2 weeks.

answers.text: Continue phenelzine; add perioperative linezolid prophylaxis for surgical site infection coverage; treat hypotension with ephedrine boluses as needed.
answers.explanation: Linezolid is a reversible MAOI and can precipitate serotonin syndrome when combined with MAOI therapy. Ephedrine should be avoided due to unpredictable and potentially exaggerated pressor responses.

answers.text: Hold phenelzine on the morning of surgery; use ephedrine as first-line vasopressor for neuraxial hypotension and meperidine for postoperative shivering.
answers.explanation: Morning-of discontinuation does not reverse irreversible MAO inhibition, and ephedrine can cause exaggerated pressor responses. Meperidine with MAOIs risks life-threatening serotonin syndrome.

answers.text: Delay surgery for 48 hours to allow partial washout; then manage hypotension with indirect sympathomimetics and use tramadol for analgesia to reduce opioid requirements.
answers.explanation: Irreversible MAOIs require 14 days for enzyme regeneration; 48 hours is inadequate and delay is inappropriate for urgent surgery. Indirect agents and tramadol increase risks of hypertensive crisis and serotonin toxicity, respectively.

didactic:
Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) such as phenelzine and tranylcypromine are irreversible, nonselective inhibitors of MAO-A and MAO-B. Because inhibition persists until new enzyme is synthesized, clinically meaningful recovery requires at least 14 days. For urgent surgery, MAOIs are typically continued; risk mitigation focuses on avoiding triggering drugs and using appropriate hemodynamic management.

Key perioperative principles for patients on MAOIs:
- Use direct-acting vasopressors for hypotension (phenylephrine, epinephrine, norepinephrine) in small, titrated doses. Avoid indirect sympathomimetics (ephedrine, metaraminol) due to unpredictable and potentially exaggerated hypertensive responses.
- Avoid meperidine, tramadol, methylene blue, linezolid, and dextromethorphan because of the risk of serotonin syndrome (hyperthermia, clonus, autonomic instability, encephalopathy). Cocaine and tyramine-rich agents can also provoke hypertensive crises.
- Opioids without meaningful serotonergic activity (morphine, hydromorphone, fentanyl, sufentanil) are generally safe when titrated. For postoperative shivering, use alternatives (eg, clonidine, dexmedetomidine) rather than meperidine.
- Local anesthetics with epinephrine and direct-acting vasoconstrictors can be used cautiously with careful titration and monitoring. Avoid pseudoephedrine and phenylpropanolamine.
- If considering discontinuation for an elective case, coordinate with psychiatry to balance relapse risk against interaction risk; any washout requires at least 2 weeks and should be planned and monitored by the psychiatric team.

Practical approach: For urgent procedures, proceed while continuing the MAOI, avoid meperidine and indirect sympathomimetics, and treat hypotension with direct-acting vasopressors. Reserve psychiatry consultation for scenarios in which elective tapering or substitution is contemplated. This strategy minimizes the risks of serotonin toxicity and hypertensive crisis while maintaining reliable hemodynamic control.
educationalObjective: Manage MAOI therapy safely by avoiding meperidine and indirect sympathomimetics; coordinate with psychiatry if changes are needed.

questionText:
A 66-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis takes prednisone 7.5 mg every morning for the past 2 years and has cushingoid features. She presents for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic cholelithiasis. Vital signs and electrolytes are normal. She took her usual prednisone dose this morning with a sip of water. The procedure is expected to last 90 minutes with anticipated same-day admission. 

Which perioperative steroid regimen is most appropriate to provide surgical stress coverage while minimizing unnecessary dosing?

answers.text: Continue her usual prednisone dose only; no supplemental steroids are needed.
answers.explanation: Chronic daily prednisone with cushingoid features indicates likely HPA axis suppression. For a moderate-stress procedure, supplemental perioperative glucocorticoid is recommended; continuing the home dose alone risks adrenal insufficiency.

answers.text: Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV at induction, then 50 mg IV every 8 h for 24–48 h, then resume home dose.
answers.explanation: This is a major-stress regimen and is excessive for laparoscopic cholecystectomy (moderate stress), increasing risk of hyperglycemia, infection, and poor wound healing without benefit.

answers.text: Perform a cosyntropin stimulation test and delay surgery until results are available.
answers.explanation: Testing can be useful for equivocal risk, but in a patient with chronic steroids and cushingoid features, empiric coverage is appropriate and surgery need not be delayed.

answers.text: Hydrocortisone 25 mg IV at induction only, then resume home dose.
answers.explanation: This is a minor-stress regimen and is inadequate for a moderate-stress operation such as laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

answers.text: Hydrocortisone 50 mg IV at induction, then 25 mg IV every 8 h for 24 h, then resume home dose the next day.
answers.explanation: For likely HPA axis suppression undergoing a moderate-stress operation, this regimen approximates physiologic stress secretion while limiting exposure, aligning with guideline-based dosing.

didactic:
Chronic glucocorticoid therapy can suppress the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, impairing the normal cortisol surge needed to tolerate surgical stress. Risk of suppression is high with prednisone >20 mg/day for >3 weeks, any dose with cushingoid features, or recent high-dose exposure; it is low with <5 mg/day in the morning or <3 weeks of therapy. Patients at low risk should continue their usual dose without “stress-dose” steroids. If NPO, give an IV equivalent of the daily dose (hydrocortisone 20 mg ≈ prednisone 5 mg ≈ dexamethasone 0.75 mg).

Perioperative supplementation is guided by surgical stress when HPA suppression is likely:
- Minor (eg, colonoscopy, inguinal hernia): continue home dose; if suppressed, hydrocortisone 25 mg IV once at induction.
- Moderate (eg, laparoscopic cholecystectomy, total joint): hydrocortisone 50 mg IV at induction, then 25 mg IV every 8 h for 24 h; resume home dose the next day.
- Major (eg, open abdominal, cardiac): hydrocortisone 100 mg IV at induction, then 50 mg IV every 8 h for 24–48 h, taper to baseline.

This patient’s chronic prednisone 7.5 mg daily with cushingoid features indicates HPA suppression, and laparoscopic cholecystectomy is a moderate-stress operation; therefore, hydrocortisone 50 mg at induction followed by 25 mg every 8 h for 24 h is appropriate. Excessive dosing (eg, major-stress regimens or prolonged courses) increases hyperglycemia, infection risk, delirium, and impaired wound healing without proven benefit. Cosyntropin testing can be considered preoperatively when risk is uncertain (eg, prednisone 5–20 mg/day >3 weeks without cushingoid features), but it should not delay indicated surgery; empiric, stress-tiered dosing is safe and effective when suppression is likely.
educationalObjective: Plan perioperative steroid coverage in chronic users or adrenal insufficiency and avoid unnecessary high dosing.

questionText:
A 45-year-old man with a deceased-donor kidney transplant 2 years ago presents for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He takes tacrolimus 2 mg at 06:00/18:00, mycophenolate mofetil 1 g twice daily, prednisone 5 mg daily, and TMP-SMX nightly. His last tacrolimus trough was 6 ng/mL, creatinine is 1.2 mg/dL, and he has no signs of infection. He has been NPO since midnight for a 07:30 start and asks whether he should take his morning medications.

Which perioperative management of his immunosuppression is most appropriate to minimize rejection risk while avoiding unnecessary infection risk?

answers.text: Convert to an intravenous tacrolimus infusion via a central venous catheter for the perioperative period
answers.explanation: IV tacrolimus requires central access and close monitoring and increases line-related infection risk; it is reserved for prolonged inability to take enteral medications, not routine elective cases where oral dosing is feasible.

answers.text: Administer the morning tacrolimus and mycophenolate with a small sip of water and resume dosing as soon as possible postoperatively; continue prednisone
answers.explanation: Continuing critical immunosuppressants through the perioperative period prevents rejection; small sips of water are acceptable when NPO, and early postoperative resumption limits trough variability without adding infection risk.

answers.text: Hold tacrolimus and mycophenolate on the morning of surgery to reduce perioperative infection risk
answers.explanation: Withholding calcineurin inhibitors or antimetabolites increases acute rejection risk; continuing baseline immunosuppression does not meaningfully increase immediate perioperative infection risk in a stable, afebrile patient.

answers.text: Give stress-dose hydrocortisone and hold tacrolimus and mycophenolate to balance rejection and infection risks
answers.explanation: Even if stress-dose steroids are considered for chronic prednisone use, they are not a substitute for calcineurin inhibitors/antimetabolites; holding these agents increases rejection risk without proven infection benefit.

answers.text: Delay the morning tacrolimus dose until after perioperative cefazolin to avoid a drug–drug interaction
answers.explanation: Cefazolin does not significantly interact with tacrolimus. Important tacrolimus interactions include macrolides and azoles (CYP3A4 inhibitors) and should be avoided or monitored, not routine cefazolin.

didactic:
Solid-organ transplant recipients should generally **continue critical immunosuppressants** (eg, tacrolimus/cyclosporine and mycophenolate/azathioprine) throughout the perioperative period to prevent acute rejection. For most elective cases, patients may take their morning doses with a **small sip of water** despite NPO status, and medications should be **resumed early postoperatively**. Skipping even a single dose of a calcineurin inhibitor can lower trough levels and increase rejection risk without conferring a meaningful reduction in immediate infection risk.

Key considerations to minimize both rejection and infection:

- Continue baseline **calcineurin inhibitor** and **antimetabolite** dosing; arrange trough monitoring only if clinically indicated or if interacting drugs are used.
- Maintain **strict asepsis** and use standard, procedure-specific antibiotic prophylaxis (eg, cefazolin for clean-contaminated abdominal surgery). Avoid unnecessary broad-spectrum therapy.
- Avoid **unnecessary lines and catheters**; central venous access increases infection risk and is not required solely for immunosuppressant administration.
- Be vigilant for **drug interactions** that raise calcineurin inhibitor levels (eg, macrolides, azoles, diltiazem/verapamil, grapefruit) or increase nephrotoxicity (eg, aminoglycosides, NSAIDs). Cefazolin does not meaningfully interact with tacrolimus.
- Continue chronic **prednisone**; consider procedure-specific stress-dose steroids if there is suspected HPA axis suppression and moderate/major surgical stress, but steroids do not replace calcineurin inhibitors/antimetabolites.
- Continue indicated **opportunistic prophylaxis** (eg, TMP-SMX) and optimize glycemic control and normothermia to reduce infection risk.

When prolonged NPO status is anticipated, alternatives include **enteral suspensions via NG/OG** or carefully monitored **IV tacrolimus** (usually via central access) in coordination with the transplant team. For routine elective cases with short fasting intervals, oral continuation with a sip of water is the safest and most effective strategy to protect the graft while minimizing infection risk.
educationalObjective: Protect immunosuppressed and transplant patients by continuing critical agents and minimizing infection risk.

questionText: A 62-year-old man with type 2 diabetes (A1c 7.6%), CAD, and CKD stage 3 presents for elective laparoscopic sigmoid colectomy. Medications include metformin 1 g BID, insulin glargine 10 U nightly, and empagliflozin 25 mg daily, which he mistakenly stopped only yesterday morning. He has been NPO since midnight and reports mild nausea without abdominal pain. Vitals are stable. Preoperative labs show capillary glucose 158 mg/dL, VBG pH 7.29, HCO<sub>3</sub> 15 mEq/L, PCO<sub>2</sub> 30 mmHg; Na 138 mEq/L, K 4.8 mEq/L, Cl 100 mEq/L (anion gap 23), lactate 1.5 mmol/L, and serum β-hydroxybutyrate 4.2 mmol/L. Urinalysis shows 3+ glucosuria and 1+ ketones. The surgeon asks if the case can proceed today. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to optimize perioperative management?

answers.text: Treat as starvation ketosis with dextrose-only infusion and proceed once glucose is ≤180 mg/dL
answers.explanation: Starvation ketosis alone is unlikely with this degree of anion gap and β-hydroxybutyrate; euglycemic DKA requires insulin plus dextrose, not dextrose alone, and surgery should be delayed.

answers.text: Proceed with surgery under general anesthesia and manage glucose with subcutaneous correctional insulin
answers.explanation: Proceeding despite an anion gap metabolic acidosis with elevated β-hydroxybutyrate is unsafe; euglycemic DKA requires insulin infusion plus dextrose and resolution of the anion gap before elective surgery.

answers.text: Initiate an IV insulin infusion with dextrose-containing fluids and postpone surgery until the anion gap closes; hold the SGLT2 inhibitor for ≥3 days before rescheduling
answers.explanation: Findings are diagnostic of euglycemic DKA from recent SGLT2 inhibitor use; best management is insulin infusion, dextrose, and fluids with postponement until the acidosis resolves. For future elective surgery, stop SGLT2 inhibitors at least 3 days (4 days for ertugliflozin) beforehand.

answers.text: Administer 1–2 L isotonic crystalloid now and proceed if symptoms improve
answers.explanation: Fluids are necessary but insufficient; SGLT2-related euglycemic DKA requires insulin to suppress ketogenesis with concurrent dextrose to avoid hypoglycemia, and elective surgery should be postponed.

answers.text: Give IV sodium bicarbonate to correct acidosis and proceed once HCO<sub>3</sub> is ≥20 mEq/L
answers.explanation: Bicarbonate is not indicated for mild–moderate DKA and does not treat the underlying ketogenesis; proceeding before closing the anion gap risks instability.

didactic:
SGLT2 inhibitors (eg, empagliflozin, canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, ertugliflozin) increase urinary glucose loss, lowering circulating insulin and increasing glucagon. This hormonal shift promotes lipolysis and hepatic ketogenesis, predisposing to **euglycemic DKA (EDKA)**, particularly with perioperative fasting, low-carbohydrate intake, dehydration, acute illness, or reduced insulin dosing. Because glycemia is often 100–250 mg/dL, EDKA can be missed unless ketones and acid–base status are assessed.

Diagnosis is suggested by an **anion gap metabolic acidosis** (low HCO<sub>3</sub>, elevated anion gap), **elevated serum β-hydroxybutyrate** (preferred over urine ketones, which may underestimate severity), and relatively modest glucose, with lactate not explaining the gap. In this case, pH 7.29, HCO<sub>3</sub> 15 mEq/L, anion gap 23, and β-hydroxybutyrate 4.2 mmol/L are diagnostic of EDKA.

Management mirrors DKA but requires early dextrose because glucose is not markedly elevated:
- **Fluids:** Isotonic crystalloid resuscitation.
- **Insulin:** IV infusion (eg, 0.05–0.1 U/kg/h) to suppress ketogenesis; monitor K<sup>+</sup> and replace as needed.
- **Dextrose:** Add D5/D10 to maintain euglycemia while continuing insulin until the anion gap closes and β-hydroxybutyrate normalizes.
- **Hold SGLT2 inhibitor** and treat precipitating factors.

Elective surgery should be **postponed** until acidosis resolves and the patient is clinically stable. For prevention, **stop SGLT2 inhibitors ≥3 days** (72 h) before elective procedures to allow resolution of pharmacodynamic effects; **ertugliflozin should be held 4 days**. If the drug was not held appropriately, or in high-risk patients, obtain a VBG/ABG, basic metabolic panel, and serum β-hydroxybutyrate before proceeding. Postoperatively, resume SGLT2 inhibitors only when the patient is hemodynamically stable, eating, and free of acidosis. This approach reduces perioperative EDKA risk while maintaining safe glycemic control.
educationalObjective: Recognize risk of euglycemic ketoacidosis with SGLT2 inhibitors and manage preoperative discontinuation and monitoring.

questionText:
A 58-year-old man with decompensated alcoholic cirrhosis presents for urgent open repair of an incarcerated umbilical hernia within 4 hours. He has refractory ascites requiring monthly large-volume paracenteses and episodic hepatic encephalopathy controlled with lactulose and rifaximin. Vitals are stable; exam shows tense ascites and mild asterixis. Labs: Hb 9.4 g/dL, platelets 54,000/μL, INR 2.0, aPTT 40 s, fibrinogen 95 mg/dL, total bilirubin 4.2 mg/dL, albumin 2.5 g/dL, creatinine 1.4 mg/dL, Na 129 mEq/L. He is Child-Pugh class C; MELD-Na is 23. The team requests guidance on preoperative optimization.

Which preoperative intervention is most appropriate to optimize hemostasis before induction?

answers.text: Administer cryoprecipitate to target fibrinogen ≥150 mg/dL before surgery
answers.explanation: Hypofibrinogenemia (<100–150 mg/dL) is a correctable contributor to bleeding in cirrhosis; cryoprecipitate (or fibrinogen concentrate) raises fibrinogen efficiently and is recommended to achieve ≥150 mg/dL for surgical hemostasis.

answers.text: Transfuse fresh frozen plasma to normalize INR to <1.5 preoperatively
answers.explanation: In cirrhosis, INR does not predict bleeding risk due to rebalanced hemostasis; prophylactic FFP to “normalize” INR adds volume (worsening portal hypertension/ascites) without clear benefit and is not recommended unless there is active bleeding or planned high-risk invasive procedure guided by viscoelastic testing.

answers.text: Initiate 3% hypertonic saline to correct Na from 129 to 135 mEq/L over the next 4 hours
answers.explanation: Rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia risks osmotic demyelination; Na should be corrected slowly (generally ≤6–8 mEq/L per 24 h) and this intervention does not address hemostasis.

answers.text: Transfuse platelets to raise the count to ≥100,000/μL before incision
answers.explanation: For most non-neurosurgical operations, a platelet threshold of ≥50,000/μL is adequate; routine escalation to ≥100,000/μL is unnecessary and exposes the patient to transfusion risks without proven reduction in bleeding.

answers.text: Withhold lactulose and give midazolam 2 mg for anxiolysis to reduce aspiration risk and agitation
answers.explanation: Withholding lactulose risks precipitating encephalopathy, and benzodiazepines can worsen encephalopathy; this does not improve hemostasis and may harm the patient’s neurocognitive status.

didactic:
Severe cirrhosis increases perioperative risk through portal hypertension, impaired synthetic function, and multisystem effects. Risk stratification with **Child-Pugh** (bilirubin, albumin, INR, ascites, encephalopathy) and **MELD-Na** (bilirubin, INR, creatinine, Na) helps determine urgency and feasibility; Child-Pugh C or MELD-Na >20 predicts high morbidity/mortality, favoring deferral unless surgery is urgent.

Cirrhotic coagulopathy is **rebalanced**: decreases in procoagulants are offset by reductions in anticoagulants and increased von Willebrand factor. Consequently, **INR is unreliable** for bleeding risk and should not be prophylactically “corrected” with FFP. Instead, target correctable defects that correlate with bleeding:
- **Fibrinogen**: Levels <100–150 mg/dL predict bleeding; give **cryoprecipitate** (or fibrinogen concentrate) to achieve ≥150 mg/dL.
- **Platelets**: For most non-neurosurgical procedures, a threshold of **≥50,000/μL** is adequate; higher targets are generally unnecessary.
- **Viscoelastic testing (TEG/ROTEM)** can guide product therapy if available, especially during active bleeding or high-risk cases.

Optimize other decompensation features:
- **Ascites**: When time allows, perform large-volume paracentesis with **albumin replacement** (≈6–8 g per liter removed when >5 L) to improve respiratory mechanics and reduce wound complications/hernia recurrence.
- **Encephalopathy**: **Continue lactulose** (± rifaximin) to maintain 2–3 soft stools/day; **avoid benzodiazepines** and minimize opioids that can precipitate encephalopathy.
- **Hyponatremia (Na<sup>+</sup>)**: Correct slowly (generally ≤6–8 mEq/L per 24 h) to avoid osmotic demyelination; reserve hypertonic saline for severe symptomatic cases.

Key takeaway: In cirrhosis, do not chase the INR. Prioritize targeted correction of hypofibrinogenemia and severe thrombocytopenia, use VET when available, control ascites with albumin-supported paracentesis, and maintain encephalopathy therapy to safely navigate the perioperative period.
educationalObjective: Assess cirrhosis severity (e.g., MELD/Child‑Pugh) and mitigate coagulopathy, ascites, and encephalopathy.

questionText:
A 56-year-old woman with idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (WHO group 1) on sildenafil and ambrisentan presents for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Preoperative echocardiography shows severe RV dilation with reduced function (TAPSE 1.2 cm), moderate tricuspid regurgitation, and estimated RVSP 70 mmHg; LV function is normal. A radial arterial line and central venous catheter are placed pre-induction.

After insufflation and Trendelenburg, she becomes acutely unstable: MAP 48 mmHg, HR 110/min, SpO<sub>2</sub> 90% on FiO<sub>2</sub> 0.6, ETCO<sub>2</sub> 55 mmHg, CVP 16 mmHg, peak airway pressure 35 cm H2O. An ABG shows pH 7.27, PaCO<sub>2</sub> 58 mmHg, PaO<sub>2</sub> 62 mmHg. A 100 μg phenylephrine bolus yields minimal improvement. Inhaled nitric oxide and inhaled epoprostenol are available in the OR.

Which immediate intervention is most appropriate to improve systemic perfusion while reducing RV afterload in this patient?

answers.text: Start dobutamine infusion and hyperventilate to PaCO<sub>2</sub> 30 mmHg
answers.explanation: Dobutamine may improve RV inotropy but often lowers SVR and can aggravate hypotension; aggressive hyperventilation risks dynamic hyperinflation and increased intrathoracic pressure, potentially worsening RV output.

answers.text: Administer a 1 L crystalloid bolus and increase FiO<sub>2</sub> to 1.0
answers.explanation: Raising FiO<sub>2</sub> is appropriate, but a large fluid bolus risks RV overdistension, worsening septal shift and CO; volume should be judicious and guided by hemodynamics or TEE.

answers.text: Start vasopressin infusion (eg, 0.01–0.03 U/min) and initiate inhaled epoprostenol via the circuit
answers.explanation: Vasopressin increases SVR with minimal effect on PVR (and may decrease PVR at low doses), augmenting RV coronary perfusion, while inhaled epoprostenol provides selective pulmonary vasodilation to acutely reduce RV afterload without systemic hypotension.

answers.text: Start milrinone infusion and nitroglycerin
answers.explanation: Milrinone reduces PVR but causes systemic vasodilation and hypotension; adding nitroglycerin further lowers preload and SVR, likely worsening perfusion in an already hypotensive patient.

answers.text: Begin phenylephrine infusion and increase PEEP to 15 cm H2O
answers.explanation: Phenylephrine (pure α) increases PVR and can worsen RV output; high PEEP impedes venous return and elevates RV afterload via alveolar overdistension, further compromising RV stroke volume.

didactic:
Severe pulmonary hypertension with RV dysfunction is highly vulnerable to precipitants that increase PVR or decrease RV perfusion pressure. Hypoxemia, hypercarbia, acidosis, high intrathoracic pressures (eg, pneumoperitoneum, excessive PEEP, overdistension), sympathetic surges, and embolic phenomena all raise PVR and precipitate acute RV failure. In this scenario, hypoxemia, hypercarbia, and pneumoperitoneum have increased PVR while systemic hypotension has reduced RV coronary perfusion pressure.

Immediate goals are to: 
- Optimize oxygenation and ventilation (FiO<sub>2</sub> 1.0, avoid hypercarbia and acidosis, target PaCO<sub>2</sub> ~35–40 mmHg) 
- Reduce RV afterload with selective pulmonary vasodilators 
- Support systemic perfusion pressure without increasing PVR 
- Avoid RV overdistension and minimize airway pressures (moderate V<sub>T</sub> 6–8 mL/kg, PEEP 5–8 cm H2O)

Inhaled nitric oxide (20–40 ppm) or inhaled epoprostenol (eg, 20–50 ng/kg/min) is preferred for acute decompensation because these agents vasodilate ventilated lung units, lowering PVR and improving V/Q matching without systemic hypotension. Systemic vasodilators (eg, milrinone, nitroglycerin) can further decrease SVR and worsen shock unless robust vasopressor support is in place.

To maintain RV perfusion, use vasopressors that raise SVR while minimizing pulmonary vasoconstriction. Vasopressin (0.01–0.03 U/min) is advantageous because it increases SVR with neutral or reduced PVR; norepinephrine is also acceptable and often first-line. Avoid phenylephrine because pure α-agonism can increase PVR and reduce RV output. Inotropes (dobutamine, epinephrine) may be necessary for cardiogenic components but can lower SVR; combine cautiously with vasopressors.

Monitoring should include an arterial line and consideration of TEE or a PA catheter to guide preload, RV function, and afterload therapy. Additionally, request lower insufflation pressures or conversion to open if pneumoperitoneum is driving RV failure. The combination of an inhaled pulmonary vasodilator with a PVR-sparing vasopressor rapidly addresses both elevated PVR and low systemic pressure.
educationalObjective: Identify pulmonary hypertension and right‑heart dysfunction and plan vasodilators, vasopressors, and monitoring.

questionText:
A 62-year-old man with type 1 diabetes mellitus for 30 years presents for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He reports lightheadedness when standing and early satiety. Preoperative vitals: supine BP 128/76 mmHg, HR 96; standing BP 98/62 mmHg, HR 98. HbA1c is 8.7%; preoperative glucose is 174 mg/dL. After induction with propofol, fentanyl, and rocuronium and initiation of sevoflurane at 1.0 MAC, his MAP falls to 52 mmHg with HR 88. SpO<sub>2</sub> 100%, ETCO<sub>2</sub> 34 mmHg. He has received 200 mL lactated Ringer’s. 

Which intraoperative management is most appropriate to address both the hemodynamic instability and diabetes-related risk in this patient?

answers.text: Administer phenylephrine 100 µg IV and give a 250–500 mL crystalloid bolus; begin glucose checks every 60 min
answers.explanation: Direct-acting α-agonists (eg, phenylephrine) more reliably restore SVR in autonomic neuropathy, and a modest fluid bolus addresses preload dependence after induction. Hourly glucose monitoring mitigates hypoglycemia unawareness under anesthesia.

answers.text: Start an epinephrine infusion at 0.02 µg/kg/min, avoid α-agonists, and check glucose every 2–3 h
answers.explanation: Epinephrine is unnecessarily β-stimulatory for isolated vasodilatory hypotension and can increase lactate and dysglycemia. Avoiding α-agonists is incorrect; direct α-agonists are preferred. Glucose checks every 2–3 h are inadequate.

answers.text: Give metoclopramide 10 mg IV and decrease sevoflurane; recheck glucose in 2 h
answers.explanation: Metoclopramide treats gastroparesis/aspiration risk but does not correct autonomically mediated hypotension. Reducing anesthetic depth alone is insufficient, and 2-hour glucose intervals are too infrequent for high-risk diabetics.

answers.text: Give a 500 mL crystalloid bolus only and avoid vasopressors; check glucose only if >250 mg/dL
answers.explanation: Volume alone often fails to correct vasodilatory hypotension from autonomic failure and anesthetic agents; vasopressors are typically required. Restricting glucose checks risks missing hypoglycemia, which may be clinically silent under anesthesia.

answers.text: Administer ephedrine 10 mg IV now and plan to check glucose at the end of the case
answers.explanation: Ephedrine (indirect sympathomimetic) relies on endogenous norepinephrine release, which is blunted in autonomic neuropathy; it is often ineffective. Deferring glucose checks risks unrecognized hypo-/hyperglycemia in a patient with impaired counterregulation.

didactic:
Long-standing diabetes can cause **autonomic neuropathy** with impaired baroreflexes, resting tachycardia, orthostatic hypotension, and **hypoglycemia unawareness**. After induction, these patients are prone to profound vasodilatory hypotension with minimal reflex tachycardia. Because presynaptic sympathetic function is impaired, **indirect-acting agents** (eg, ephedrine, which releases endogenous norepinephrine) may be ineffective. In contrast, **direct-acting vasopressors** (eg, phenylephrine, vasopressin) reliably increase SVR and MAP when hypotension follows induction or pneumoperitoneum.

Key intraoperative priorities:
- Hemodynamics: Expect **preload dependence** and vasodilation with anesthetic agents. Treat acute hypotension with a **direct-acting α-agonist** and a modest crystalloid bolus; titrate to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg. Consider an arterial line if instability persists or major fluid shifts are expected.
- Glucose monitoring: Autonomic neuropathy blunts adrenergic warning signs; anesthesia further masks symptoms. Use **frequent glucose checks (eg, every 60 min)**—especially if any insulin is administered—to avoid occult hypoglycemia and wide excursions. Target 140–180 mg/dL and avoid “tight control” to reduce hypoglycemia risk.
- Adjuncts: Gastroparesis raises aspiration risk; consider RSI and pharmacologic prophylaxis, but these do not treat hypotension. Reduce volatile dose as tolerated (diabetics may need less anesthetic) while prioritizing perfusion.

In this patient with orthostatic hypotension and minimal heart rate response, the best immediate strategy is **phenylephrine** to restore SVR, plus a **250–500 mL crystalloid bolus** to support preload, along with institution of **hourly glucose monitoring** to mitigate hypoglycemia unawareness. Indirect agents (ephedrine), delayed glucose checks, or relying on fluids alone are common pitfalls that fail to address the pathophysiology of diabetic autonomic neuropathy.
educationalObjective: Manage diabetes and autonomic neuropathy intraoperatively with tight glucose monitoring and hemodynamic vigilance.

questionText:
A 68-year-old man with severe COPD (FEV1 35% predicted) presents for elective open inguinal hernia repair. He smokes 1 pack/day, uses tiotropium daily and albuterol as needed, and finished antibiotics for a “chest cold” 3 days ago. He reports ongoing wheeze and productive cough. On exam, he has diffuse expiratory wheezes; SpO<sub>2</sub> 90% on room air. ABG: pH 7.36, PaCO<sub>2</sub> 52 mmHg, PaO<sub>2</sub> 60 mmHg. CXR shows hyperinflation without infiltrate. The surgeon is willing to delay if needed.

Which perioperative strategy is most appropriate to minimize intraoperative air trapping and postoperative pulmonary complications?

answers.text: Start prophylactic antibiotics and proceed; increase RR to normalize ETCO<sub>2</sub> and apply PEEP 10 cm H2O to prevent atelectasis.
answers.explanation: Antibiotics are not indicated without infection; normalizing ETCO<sub>2</sub> by increasing RR shortens expiratory time, and high PEEP worsens air trapping in severe obstruction.

answers.text: Proceed with spinal anesthesia to avoid general anesthesia; no additional optimization is necessary if the block is adequate.
answers.explanation: Neuraxial anesthesia does not address active bronchospasm and may still require sedation; optimization and obstructive-friendly ventilatory strategy remain important if conversion or sedation is needed.

answers.text: Proceed as scheduled; use desflurane for rapid titration and volume control ventilation with Vt 8 mL/kg ideal body weight (IBW), RR 16/min, I:E 1:2, and PEEP 8 cm H2O to maintain oxygenation.
answers.explanation: Desflurane is airway-irritating and can provoke bronchospasm; a high RR and shorter expiratory time with higher PEEP promote dynamic hyperinflation and auto-PEEP.

answers.text: Delay surgery to optimize with scheduled inhaled short-acting bronchodilator plus anticholinergic and a short (3–5 day) prednisone course; then use sevoflurane with Vt 6 mL/kg IBW, RR 8/min, I:E 1:4, minimal PEEP (0–3 cm H2O), and permissive hypercapnia.
answers.explanation: Treating active bronchospasm and prolonging expiratory time with low Vt/low RR minimizes air trapping; sevoflurane provides bronchodilation, and minimal PEEP reduces dynamic hyperinflation risk.

answers.text: Begin a long-acting β<sub>2</sub>-agonist and avoid anticholinergics; use nitrous oxide with Vt 10 mL/kg IBW, RR 12/min, and I:E 1:1 to improve ventilation.
answers.explanation: Anticholinergics are first-line in COPD; N<sub>2</sub>O can expand bullae, and larger Vt with short expiratory time increases dynamic hyperinflation.

didactic:
Patients with obstructive lung disease are at risk for intraoperative bronchospasm and dynamic hyperinflation (auto-PEEP) due to prolonged expiratory time constants. Preoperative priorities are to avoid surgery during an exacerbation and optimize airflow: delay elective procedures when wheezing persists, intensify inhaled bronchodilators (short-acting β<sub>2</sub>-agonist plus anticholinergic), and consider a short course of systemic corticosteroids (eg, prednisone 20–40 mg daily for 3–5 days) if bronchospasm is present. Encourage smoking cessation, airway clearance, and treat infection only when clinical criteria are met. 

Intraoperatively, the ventilatory strategy should reduce gas trapping by allowing complete exhalation:
- Low Vt (6–8 mL/kg ideal body weight) and low RR (eg, 8–10/min) to lower minute ventilation demands.
- Prolonged expiratory time (I:E 1:3 to 1:5) by shortening inspiratory time and avoiding unnecessary inspiratory pause.
- Minimal external PEEP (0–5 cm H2O), as excessive PEEP can add to intrinsic PEEP in severe COPD and worsen hyperinflation; titrate to oxygenation while monitoring for auto-PEEP via an expiratory hold.
- Accept permissive hypercapnia with adequate oxygenation (eg, FiO<sub>2</sub> titrated to SpO<sub>2</sub> 88%–92%) rather than increasing RR, which shortens expiratory time.
- Use volatile agents with bronchodilatory properties (eg, sevoflurane, isoflurane) and avoid airway irritants (desflurane) and histamine-releasing drugs when possible.

If severe dynamic hyperinflation occurs (rising plateau/peak pressures, hypotension, expiratory flow not returning to baseline), transiently disconnect the circuit to allow full exhalation, deepen anesthesia, administer inhaled β<sub>2</sub>-agonists, and re-set the ventilator with a longer expiratory phase. Avoid N<sub>2</sub>O in suspected bullous disease. This combined preoperative optimization and obstructive-friendly ventilation reduces perioperative pulmonary complications and hemodynamic instability from auto-PEEP.
educationalObjective: Optimize COPD and asthma preoperatively and tailor intraoperative ventilation to avoid air trapping.

questionText:
A 48-year-old man (BMI 52 kg/m<sup>2</sup>) with obstructive sleep apnea on nightly CPAP, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes presents for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He is appropriately fasted but has symptomatic GERD. Sitting, his SpO<sub>2</sub> is 95% on room air, which falls to 90% when supine. Airway exam: Mallampati III, thyromental distance 6 cm, neck circumference 48 cm. You plan a rapid-sequence induction.

Which intraoperative plan best optimizes first-pass intubation and oxygenation while using appropriate dosing scalars and ventilation in this patient?

answers.text: Reverse Trendelenburg only after intubation; preoxygenation via high-flow nasal cannula alone; propofol 1 mg/kg ideal body weight; rocuronium 1.2 mg/kg total body weight; V<sub>T</sub> 6 mL/kg total body weight; PEEP 5 cm H<sub>2</sub>O.
answers.explanation: Head-up during preoxygenation is omitted, propofol is underdosed, nondepolarizer is overdosed using TBW, V<sub>T</sub> is inappropriately scaled to TBW, and PEEP is inadequate.

answers.text: Ramped, head-elevated (20–25°) position with CPAP 10 cm H<sub>2</sub>O during preoxygenation; induction with propofol 2 mg/kg lean body weight and succinylcholine 1.5 mg/kg total body weight; post-intubation V<sub>T</sub> 6–8 mL/kg ideal body weight with PEEP 10–12 cm H<sub>2</sub>O.
answers.explanation: This integrates optimal positioning and preoxygenation to increase FRC, correct dosing scalars (propofol by LBW; succinylcholine by TBW), and lung-protective ventilation with adequate PEEP in morbid obesity.

answers.text: Ramped position; preoxygenation with 100% O<sub>2</sub> without PEEP; propofol 2 mg/kg ideal body weight; succinylcholine 1 mg/kg total body weight; V<sub>T</sub> 6 mL/kg ideal body weight; PEEP 5 cm H<sub>2</sub>O.
answers.explanation: Although ramping is appropriate, preoxygenation without PEEP and low intraoperative PEEP are suboptimal; propofol by IBW underdoses induction and succinylcholine at 1 mg/kg TBW is less reliable for RSI in morbid obesity.

answers.text: Supine sniffing position; preoxygenation with 100% O<sub>2</sub> by facemask only; propofol 2 mg/kg total body weight; succinylcholine 1 mg/kg ideal body weight; V<sub>T</sub> 10 mL/kg total body weight; zero PEEP.
answers.explanation: Overdoses propofol and tidal volume, underdoses succinylcholine, omits PEEP, and forgoes head-elevated positioning—promoting rapid desaturation and poor intubating conditions.

answers.text: Sniffing position with apneic oxygenation via nasal cannula; propofol 3 mg/kg lean body weight; succinylcholine 0.6 mg/kg total body weight; V<sub>T</sub> 8 mL/kg ideal body weight; zero PEEP.
answers.explanation: Excessive propofol risks hypotension, succinylcholine is underdosed for RSI, and absence of PEEP with non-head-elevated positioning accelerates desaturation.

didactic:
Morbid obesity reduces FRC and ERV, increases O<sub>2</sub> consumption, and moves closing capacity toward tidal breathing, producing rapid desaturation during apnea and difficult mask ventilation. Airway and ventilation strategies should increase oxygen reserve and maintain alveolar patency. A ramped, head-elevated laryngoscopy position (HELP) aligned with the external auditory meatus–sternal notch and 20–25° head-up improves preoxygenation, glottic view, and mask ventilation by increasing FRC and decreasing airway collapsibility.
