answers.text: Median: inject within the carpal tunnel distal to the distal wrist crease. Ulnar: dorsal subcutaneous wheal only at the ulnar styloid. Radial: no separate block needed because median and ulnar blocks cover the dorsoradial wrist.
answers.explanation: Intratunnel median injection risks nerve injury; a dorsal-only ulnar wheal omits palmar ulnar distribution; the superficial radial nerve supplies dorsoradial wrist and requires its own subcutaneous block.

answers.text: Median: inject between the flexor carpi radialis tendon and the radial artery. Ulnar: inject within Guyon canal distal to the pisiform. Radial: palmar subcutaneous infiltration along the thenar crease.
answers.explanation: Median placement is too radial; ulnar injection within Guyon canal risks intraneural injury and misses dorsal branch; palmar infiltration does not block the superficial radial nerve on the dorsoradial wrist.

didactic:
Wrist anesthesia for hand surgery can be reliably achieved using surface landmarks to block the **median**, **ulnar**, and **superficial radial** nerves without ultrasound. Key landmarks and techniques:

- Median nerve: Identify the palmaris longus (PL) and flexor carpi radialis (FCR) by having the patient oppose thumb and little finger and flex the wrist. The median nerve lies deep between PL and FCR at the proximal wrist crease. Insert a small needle just deep to the fascia between these tendons, aspirate, and inject 3–5 mL. If PL is absent, inject just ulnar to the FCR tendon.
- Ulnar nerve: Palpate the ulnar artery at the proximal wrist crease (just radial to flexor carpi ulnaris [FCU]). The ulnar nerve lies **ulnar (medial)** to the artery. Insert the needle just ulnar to the arterial pulse, advance 0.5–1 cm, aspirate, and inject 3–5 mL. Add a 2–3 mL subcutaneous wheal along the dorsoulnar wrist to cover the dorsal ulnar cutaneous branch.
- Superficial radial nerve: This purely sensory branch runs subcutaneously on the dorsoradial wrist, lateral to the radial artery. Perform a subdermal field block (5–10 mL) from the radial styloid across the dorsoradial wrist toward the extensor tendons, staying superficial and lateral to the radial artery.

Practical points:

- Use incremental injections with frequent aspiration to avoid intravascular injection (particularly near the ulnar and radial arteries).
- Avoid injecting within the **carpal tunnel** or **Guyon canal** to reduce intraneural injury risk; deposit local just proximal and superficial to these structures.
- Expect onset within minutes with lidocaine; adjust volume/concentration and add epinephrine judiciously (avoid end-arterial digit infiltration).

This landmark-based approach provides dense sensory anesthesia to the palmar and dorsoradial aspects of the hand and wrist while minimizing vascular and neural complications.
educationalObjective: Provide surgical anesthesia at the wrist by blocking radial, median, and ulnar nerves using surface landmarks.

questionText:
A 52-year-old man undergoes an ultrasound-guided right supraclavicular brachial plexus block with 25 mL of 0.5% ropivacaine for distal radius ORIF. Fifteen minutes later, he reports a “droopy” right eyelid and hoarseness. Examination shows right ptosis, miosis, and decreased facial sweating with mild facial flushing on the right. He has mild dyspnea when speaking, but vital signs are stable (BP 128/72 mmHg, HR 74/min, RR 16/min, SpO<sub>2</sub> 98% on room air). Breath sounds are equal without chest pain.

Which of the following best explains this constellation of findings?

answers.text: Hemidiaphragmatic paralysis from ipsilateral phrenic nerve block
answers.explanation: Phrenic nerve block can cause dyspnea, especially in patients with limited pulmonary reserve, but it does not cause ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis, or hoarseness.

answers.text: Unintended blockade of the ipsilateral cervical sympathetic chain (stellate ganglion) and recurrent laryngeal nerve from cephalad spread of local anesthetic
answers.explanation: Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) reflects ipsilateral cervical sympathetic blockade, and hoarseness reflects ipsilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve block; both can occur after interscalene/supraclavicular blocks due to cephalad spread and are typically self-limited.

answers.text: High neuraxial/brainstem anesthesia from inadvertent intrathecal spread
answers.explanation: High neuraxial spread causes hypotension, bradycardia, dyspnea/apnea, and bilateral neurologic deficits rather than unilateral Horner syndrome with isolated voice changes.

answers.text: Local anesthetic systemic toxicity from inadvertent intravascular injection
answers.explanation: LAST usually presents with CNS prodromes (tinnitus, perioral numbness, metallic taste) and can progress to seizures and cardiovascular collapse; it does not cause focal unilateral ocular findings or isolated hoarseness.

answers.text: Pneumothorax from pleural puncture during the supraclavicular approach
answers.explanation: Pneumothorax typically presents with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, hypoxemia, and decreased/unilateral breath sounds—not isolated ipsilateral Horner signs and hoarseness with normal SpO<sub>2</sub> and symmetric breath sounds.

didactic:
Interscalene and supraclavicular brachial plexus blocks can produce unintended cranial and cervical neural blockade due to anatomic proximity and cephalad spread of local anesthetic. The triad of ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, and facial anhidrosis/flushing is **Horner syndrome**, which results from blockade of the **cervical sympathetic chain (stellate ganglion)**. Concurrent **hoarseness** reflects ipsilateral **recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)** blockade from spread to the vagus/RLN within the carotid sheath. These effects are typically benign and self-limited as the block resolves.

Key differentiators from other complications:
- **Phrenic nerve block** (common with interscalene; less frequent with supraclavicular) causes hemidiaphragmatic paresis and dyspnea but not Horner syndrome or hoarseness.
- **Pneumothorax** presents with pleuritic pain, hypoxemia, and decreased/delayed breath sounds on the affected side; it is less likely with normal SpO<sub>2</sub> and symmetric auscultation.
- **Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST)** presents with CNS prodromes (tinnitus, metallic taste, perioral numbness) and can progress to seizures and dysrhythmias—findings not seen here.
- **High neuraxial spread** would cause hypotension, bradycardia, dyspnea/apnea, and bilateral sensorimotor changes.

Clinical implications:
- Horner syndrome and RLN block signify cephalad spread; they are more likely with larger volumes and higher (interscalene) approaches but can occur with supraclavicular blocks.
- RLN block is usually well tolerated, but patients with **contralateral RLN palsy** or preexisting vocal cord dysfunction are at risk for airway compromise; avoid bilateral blocks and be prepared to manage the airway if stridor or respiratory distress develops.
- Management is typically observation, reassurance, and supplemental O<sub>2</sub> as needed; symptoms resolve as local anesthetic regresses. Ultrasound guidance and lower volumes can reduce the incidence of these side effects.
educationalObjective: Recognize Horner syndrome and recurrent laryngeal nerve block after interscalene/supraclavicular approaches.

questionText:
A 48-year-old man is scheduled for open reduction and internal fixation of a 5th metacarpal fracture under an ultrasound-guided supraclavicular brachial plexus block. Thirty minutes after block completion, he cannot extend his wrist and reports numbness over the first dorsal web space and the palmar surfaces of the thumb, index, and middle fingers. However, pinprick sensation remains intact over the volar little finger and ulnar half of the ring finger, and the planned incision is along the ulnar border of the hand. The surgeon is ready to start and minimal additional sedation is preferred.

Which supplemental nerve block is the most appropriate to provide surgical anesthesia for this incision?

answers.text: Musculocutaneous nerve block within the coracobrachialis in the axilla
answers.explanation: The musculocutaneous nerve provides sensation to the lateral forearm (lateral antebrachial cutaneous nerve), not the hand.

answers.text: Radial nerve (superficial branch) block at the wrist with subcutaneous infiltration over the dorsolateral wrist
answers.explanation: The superficial radial nerve innervates the dorsolateral hand and first dorsal web space, which are already anesthetized and do not include the volar little finger.

answers.text: Median nerve block at the wrist, just ulnar to the palmaris longus tendon
answers.explanation: The median nerve supplies the palmar lateral 3½ digits, which are already anesthetized; it does not cover the volar little finger or ulnar palm.

answers.text: Ulnar nerve block at the wrist, just radial to the flexor carpi ulnaris tendon proximal to the pisiform
answers.explanation: The ulnar nerve supplies the volar little finger, ulnar half of the ring finger, and ulnar palm; a focused wrist block rapidly rescues incomplete ulnar coverage after a proximal block.

answers.text: Intercostobrachial nerve block via subcutaneous ring infiltration of the medial proximal arm
answers.explanation: The intercostobrachial nerve (T2) covers the medial upper arm and is relevant for proximal arm tourniquet discomfort, not ulnar-sided hand incisions.

didactic:
In an incomplete brachial plexus block, targeted supplementation based on sensory mapping is the fastest and safest rescue strategy. The sensory pattern in this patient—anesthetized palmar thumb/index/middle (median) and first dorsal web space (radial) with preserved pinprick on the volar little finger and ulnar half of the ring finger—is classic for incomplete ulnar nerve anesthesia. A selective ulnar nerve block at the wrist efficiently rescues this deficit without repeating a proximal block.

Key cutaneous distributions:
- Median: palmar thumb, index, middle, and radial half of ring; dorsal distal tips of index/middle.
- Ulnar: palmar little finger and ulnar half of ring; ulnar palm; dorsal ulnar hand and dorsal little/ring except distal tips.
- Radial (superficial): dorsolateral hand and first dorsal web space.
- Musculocutaneous (lateral antebrachial cutaneous): lateral forearm.
- Intercostobrachial/medial brachial cutaneous: medial upper arm (tourniquet discomfort).

Wrist block techniques (landmark-based):
- Ulnar: identify the pisiform and flexor carpi ulnaris (FCU) tendon; inject 3–5 mL just radial (lateral) to the FCU tendon proximal to the pisiform, after careful aspiration to avoid the adjacent ulnar artery.
- Median: inject 3–5 mL just ulnar to the palmaris longus and radial to the flexor carpi radialis at the wrist crease.
- Radial (superficial): subcutaneous ring infiltration lateral to the radial styloid over the dorsolateral wrist.

Although a supraclavicular block typically provides dense anesthesia to the hand, incomplete spread or fascial septa can spare a terminal nerve. Distal, nerve-specific supplementation minimizes additional local anesthetic dose, limits risk of vascular puncture in the neck/axilla, and provides rapid onset where it matters for the incision. Always inject incrementally with frequent aspiration and avoid intraneural injection, especially near the ulnar artery at the wrist.
educationalObjective: Rescue incomplete upper limb block by supplementing specific terminal nerves based on sensory mapping.

questionText: A 55-year-old man scheduled for outpatient arthroscopic rotator cuff repair asks about options for postoperative pain control. He is ASA II with normal spirometry, no OSA, and SpO₂ 98% on room air. You plan an ultrasound-guided regional technique. Which of the following is the most appropriate counseling statement regarding block choice and respiratory effects for this procedure?

answers.text: An interscalene block provides the most reliable analgesia for shoulder surgery but produces ipsilateral hemidiaphragmatic paresis in most patients (≈90%); in patients with significant lung disease, a diaphragm-sparing alternative such as combined suprascapular and axillary nerve blocks can be chosen.
answers.explanation: ISB is the gold standard for shoulder analgesia and nearly always blocks the phrenic nerve, transiently reducing FEV<sub>1</sub>/FVC by ~25–30%. For high-risk lungs, suprascapular + axillary nerve blocks (or a low-volume superior trunk block) are reasonable diaphragm-sparing options.

answers.text: An isolated axillary block is the preferred single-nerve alternative to interscalene for shoulder analgesia in patients with compromised pulmonary function.
answers.explanation: Axillary block alone does not cover the suprascapular nerve and provides inadequate shoulder analgesia; it must be combined with a suprascapular nerve block to approach ISB efficacy.

answers.text: Using ultrasound guidance and ≤5 mL of local anesthetic for the interscalene block consistently avoids phrenic nerve palsy, so dyspnea is unlikely even in severe COPD.
answers.explanation: Lower volumes and extrafascial techniques reduce but do not reliably eliminate hemidiaphragmatic paresis; clinically significant dyspnea can still occur in severe pulmonary disease.

answers.text: A supraclavicular block offers equivalent shoulder analgesia to interscalene while reliably avoiding phrenic nerve block and Horner syndrome.
answers.explanation: Supraclavicular block does not reliably cover the shoulder (suprascapular/axillary territories) and can still result in phrenic involvement; it is not preferred for shoulder surgery analgesia.

answers.text: A superior trunk block increases the likelihood of hemidiaphragmatic paresis compared with interscalene but better preserves hand motor function.
answers.explanation: Superior trunk block is more distal from the phrenic nerve and generally reduces (rather than increases) hemidiaphragmatic paresis compared with ISB, while preserving distal motor function.

didactic:
The **interscalene block (ISB)** provides the most reliable analgesia for shoulder surgery because it targets C5–C7 roots/trunks, anesthetizing the **suprascapular** and **axillary** nerves that carry most nociception from the glenohumeral joint. However, due to the phrenic nerve’s proximity on the anterior scalene (C3–C5), ISB causes **ipsilateral hemidiaphragmatic paresis** in ≈90–100% of patients, with a transient ↓ in FEV<sub>1</sub> and FVC of roughly 25–30%. Most healthy patients tolerate this without symptoms, but those with limited reserve (eg, severe COPD, contralateral diaphragm paralysis, advanced restrictive disease, morbid obesity with OSA) may experience dyspnea.

Key counseling points for ISB:
- Expect temporary ipsilateral diaphragm weakness; mild dyspnea or orthopnea can occur.
- Other transient effects include **Horner syndrome** (stellate ganglion spread) and hoarseness (recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement).
- Benefits include superior postoperative analgesia and reduced opioid use after shoulder procedures.

For patients with high pulmonary risk, consider **diaphragm-sparing alternatives**:
- **Suprascapular + axillary nerve blocks (SSNB + ANB):** Robust shoulder analgesia with minimal effect on the diaphragm; may have slightly less complete analgesia than ISB, especially for arthroplasty, but are excellent for arthroscopy.
- **Superior trunk block (STB):** More distal than ISB, lowering phrenic involvement (especially with low volumes and extrafascial deposition) while preserving hand motor function; still not entirely phrenic-sparing.
- Other strategies: reduce ISB volume (eg, 5–10 mL) and use extrafascial injection to decrease, but not eliminate, phrenic paresis.

Bottom line: For a healthy patient, an **ISB is the preferred** block for shoulder surgery, and counseling must include the high likelihood of **hemidiaphragmatic paresis**. In patients with compromised lungs, **SSNB + ANB** or a low-volume **STB** can provide effective analgesia while better preserving respiratory function.
educationalObjective: Select interscalene block for shoulder surgery and counsel about hemidiaphragmatic paresis and alternatives in high-risk lungs.

questionText:
A 68-year-old man (BMI 35) with moderate COPD (FEV1 45%) and resting SpO<sub>2</sub> 92% on room air is scheduled for arthroscopic rotator cuff repair. General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation is planned, and you intend to add a regional technique for postoperative shoulder analgesia. He becomes dyspneic with minimal exertion and wishes to avoid any breathing issues postoperatively. The surgeon expects substantial early pain and requests reliable analgesia for the first postoperative day. On ultrasound, the superior trunk is easily identified.

Which block and local anesthetic regimen best balances timely onset and duration of shoulder analgesia while minimizing the risk of hemidiaphragmatic paresis?

answers.text: Superior trunk block with 8 mL 0.5% ropivacaine
answers.explanation: Targets the superior trunk distal to the phrenic nerve with a modest volume to limit cephalad spread; a higher concentration speeds onset and provides durable analgesia while lowering the risk of diaphragmatic paresis compared with interscalene.

answers.text: Interscalene block with 20 mL 0.5% ropivacaine
answers.explanation: Provides dense, rapid analgesia but causes hemidiaphragmatic paresis in the vast majority of patients at this volume, which is unsuitable for this COPD patient.

answers.text: Superior trunk block with 15 mL 0.25% ropivacaine
answers.explanation: Excess volume increases the chance of proximal spread to the phrenic nerve, while the dilute concentration slows onset and reduces block density.

answers.text: Combined suprascapular and axillary nerve blocks with 5 mL 0.5% ropivacaine each
answers.explanation: Phrenic-sparing but may provide less dense, less reliable early analgesia compared with superior trunk techniques for arthroscopic rotator cuff repair.

answers.text: Interscalene block with 5 mL 0.25% ropivacaine
answers.explanation: Lower volume reduces spread, but the dilute concentration yields slower, less reliable onset and shorter duration; phrenic paresis can still occur with interscalene even at low volumes.

didactic:
Shoulder analgesia is traditionally achieved with an interscalene block (ISB), but hemidiaphragmatic paresis is common due to phrenic nerve proximity—rates approach 70–100% with 20 mL volumes. Reducing ISB volume can decrease, but not eliminate, paresis; even 5–10 mL may still cause clinically relevant diaphragm dysfunction in susceptible patients. Thus, patients with limited pulmonary reserve (eg, COPD) benefit from phrenic-sparing strategies.

A **superior trunk block (STB)** anesthetizes the C5–C6 fibers distal to the point where the phrenic nerve is most at risk, lowering the incidence and severity of hemidiaphragmatic paresis while providing comparable shoulder analgesia. The key trade-off is **volume vs spread**: higher volumes increase cephalad/medial spread toward the phrenic nerve, while lower volumes reduce unintended spread but risk block failure if not precisely deposited. Concentration primarily influences **onset and block density**, with higher concentrations producing faster, more reliable onset without necessarily increasing spread if total volume is contained.

For arthroscopic rotator cuff repair requiring robust early analgesia, **8 mL of 0.5% ropivacaine** at the superior trunk balances these factors: the modest volume limits phrenic involvement and the higher concentration yields timely onset and durable analgesia. Additional techniques that further reduce paresis risk include extrafascial injection and meticulous, ultrasound-guided hydrodissection to avoid medial spread.

Alternatives include low-volume ISB (still nontrivial paresis risk) and combined **suprascapular + axillary** nerve blocks (phrenic-sparing but often provide less dense early analgesia than STB/ISB for rotator cuff repairs). Overall, for high-risk respiratory patients needing reliable shoulder analgesia, a low-volume, higher-concentration STB is preferred to balance **onset, duration, and diaphragm-sparing**.
educationalObjective: Select volumes and concentrations to balance onset and avoid diaphragmatic paresis for shoulder analgesia.

questionText:
A 72-year-old tall, thin man with severe emphysema (barrel chest, home O<sub>2</sub>) is scheduled for open reduction and internal fixation of a distal radius fracture under regional anesthesia. You plan a single-shot, ultrasound-guided supraclavicular brachial plexus block to avoid general anesthesia. With a high-frequency linear probe just superior to the clavicle in the coronal-oblique plane, you identify the subclavian artery sitting atop the first rib, the brachial plexus “cluster of grapes” posterolateral to the artery, and a shimmering pleural line deeper and more medial. You want to maximize block success while minimizing pneumothorax risk during needle advancement.

Which ultrasound technique and probe/needle orientation best achieves this goal?

answers.text: Keep a more medial probe position to deepen the corner pocket and advance in-plane from medial-to-lateral toward the subclavian artery for a perivascular spread.
answers.explanation: Medial windows often lack a rib backstop, placing the plexus over the pleura; a medial-to-lateral trajectory increases pneumothorax and vascular puncture risk.

answers.text: Tilt the probe cephalad to eliminate rib shadowing and advance in-plane below the first rib to spread local anesthetic under the plexus for complete coverage.
answers.explanation: Removing the rib shadow exposes the pleura rather than protecting against it; deliberately passing below the first rib directs the needle toward the lung and is unsafe.

answers.text: Use an out-of-plane, cephalad-to-caudad approach until the needle contacts the clavicle, then walk off inferiorly toward the plexus to prevent pleural puncture.
answers.explanation: Out-of-plane advancement obscures tip location and walking off the clavicle risks losing control of depth; contact with bone does not protect the pleura once the needle slips beyond its edge.

answers.text: Slide the probe laterally until the first rib lies directly beneath the plexus; advance an in-plane needle from lateral-to-medial with a shallow trajectory, keeping the tip visualized above the rib and using hydrodissection to enter the anteroinferior “corner pocket.”
answers.explanation: Lateral probe position places the first rib as a hard backstop under the plexus; a shallow, in-plane lateral-to-medial path with continuous tip visualization and hydrodissection allows safe corner-pocket spread while avoiding the pleura.

answers.text: Rotate the probe perpendicular to the clavicle (transverse) and perform an out-of-plane injection into the plexus cluster to shorten skin-to-plexus distance.
answers.explanation: Transverse/out-of-plane techniques reduce visualization of the first rib and pleura and impair tip tracking, increasing the risk of pleural puncture and intraneural injection.

didactic:
The supraclavicular block anesthetizes the brachial plexus at the level of trunks/divisions, producing dense anesthesia for forearm and hand surgery. Despite ultrasound guidance, pneumothorax remains a key hazard because the pleural dome lies deep and medial to the subclavian artery, and the first rib slopes away medially so that the plexus may overlie pleura if the window is too medial.

Risk mitigation relies on image optimization and needle trajectory control. Position the probe in the supraclavicular fossa in a coronal-oblique orientation parallel to the clavicle. Slide the transducer laterally until the hyperechoic first rib lies directly beneath the plexus cluster; the first rib serves as a hard barrier between the needle and pleura. Identify the subclavian artery on the first rib, with the plexus posterolateral to the artery, and confirm the shimmering pleural line medial/deep to the rib. Use color Doppler to locate and avoid vascular structures.

Advance the block needle in-plane from lateral-to-medial with a shallow angle so the needle crosses the rib contour and the tip remains above the rib at all times. Maintain continuous tip visualization and use small-volume hydrodissection to separate tissue planes safely. Deposit part of the local anesthetic in the anteroinferior “corner pocket” (between the artery and first rib) to reliably capture the lower trunk/ulnar distribution, then complete a perineural, circumferential spread around the plexus—all while keeping the tip on the rib side, never below it. Avoid medial-to-lateral or out-of-plane approaches, which decrease tip control and increase contact with unprotected pleura.

If a safe lateral window with a rib backstop cannot be obtained, consider an alternative technique (eg, infraclavicular or superior trunk block) rather than forcing a medial supraclavicular approach in patients with high pneumothorax risk.
educationalObjective: Use supraclavicular block for distal arm surgery and mitigate pneumothorax risk with ultrasound technique and probe orientation.
